title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: didet package provides tools differences--differences () estimation treatment variable interest may non-binary value may change time period. package implements doubly robust estimation average treatment effect movers using concept effective treatment. methods developed Yanagi (2023) “effective treatment approach difference--differences general treatment patterns”.

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: Get package GitHub:

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: didet package provides following function: didet(): estimation general treatment patterns using concept effective treatment.

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: didet() function following arguments: yname: name outcome variable dname: name treatment variable tname: name time period idname: name unit index xformla: formula unit-specific covariates included. form xformla = ~ X + Z. Default xformla = ~ 1. data: data.frame balanced panel data (long format) specification: character specifying effective treatment function. Options “”, “event”, “number”, “aggregate”. Default “event”. alp: significance level. Default 0.05. nboot: number bootstrap repetitions. Default 1000.

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: didet() function returns list contains following elements: ATEM: data.frame collects estimation results \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, e)\) \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, r, e)\). mover: data.frame collects estimation results probabilities movers. stayer: data.frame collects estimation results probabilities stayers. figure: list contains ggplot2 figures \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t,s,e)\) \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, r, e)\).

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: begin generating artificial balanced panel data using datageneration() function.
code: # Generate artificial balanced panel data # N: The number of the cross-sectional units # S: The length of the time series set.seed(1) data <- didet::datageneration(N = 1000, S = 4) head(data) #>   id period          Y D          X once event number #> 1  1      1 -0.1819699 0 -0.6264538    0     0      0 #> 2  1      2  2.2096505 1 -0.6264538    1     2      1 #> 3  1      3  1.4318668 0 -0.6264538    1     2      1 #> 4  1      4  2.8392303 1 -0.6264538    1     2      2 #> 5  2      1 -0.6832054 0  0.1836433    0     0      0 #> 6  2      2  4.9496969 0  0.1836433    0     0      0

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: estimation using event specification: ATEM estimation results : rows r equal NA present estimation results \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, e)\), , estimation results “post-treatment periods”. example, first row shows estimation results \(\mathrm{ATEM}(2, 1, 2)\), average treatment effect period 2 (\(t = 2\)) movers comparison units period \(1\) (\(s = 1\)) whose event date period 2 (\(e = 2\)). rows r unequal NA correspond estimation results \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, r, e)\), , estimation results “pre-treatment periods”, approximately 0 parallel trends assumption. resulting figures :    figures, dots bars correspond ATEM estimates \(1 - \alpha\) uniform confidence bands, x-axis indicating time period \(t\).

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: estimation using specification: ATEM estimation results : resulting figure :
code: # DiD estimation did_est <- didet::didet(yname = "Y",                         dname = "D",                         tname = "period",                         idname = "id",                         xformla = ~ X,                         data = data,                         specification = "once",                         alp = 0.05,                         nboot = 1000) # DiD estimation did_est$ATEM #>   t s  r e       est        SE       CIL      CIU #> 1 2 1 NA 1 0.6573026 0.1626075 0.2683060 1.046299 #> 2 3 1 NA 1 1.2173456 0.1593353 0.8361769 1.598514 #> 3 4 1 NA 1 1.1711503 0.2263077 0.6297673 1.712533 did_est$figure$e1

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: estimation using number specification: ATEM estimation results : resulting figures :    last two figures, estimation results \(t = 2\) \(t \\{ 2, 3 \}\) suppressed units experienced two three times treatment adoptions time periods.
code: # DiD estimation did_est <- didet::didet(yname = "Y",                         dname = "D",                         tname = "period",                         idname = "id",                         xformla = ~ X,                         data = data,                         specification = "number",                         alp = 0.05,                         nboot = 1000) # DiD estimation did_est$ATEM #>   t s  r e       est        SE       CIL      CIU #> 1 2 1 NA 1 0.6573026 0.1686379 0.2142356 1.100370 #> 2 3 1 NA 1 1.1656749 0.1657341 0.7302370 1.601113 #> 3 4 1 NA 1 0.8323819 0.1951119 0.3197590 1.345005 #> 4 3 1 NA 2 1.2696071 0.2119726 0.7126857 1.826529 #> 5 4 1 NA 2 1.3969331 0.2810274 0.6585820 2.135284 #> 6 4 1 NA 3 1.1196405 0.3190303 0.2814431 1.957838 # Number of treatment adoptions = 1 did_est$figure$e1 # Number of treatment adoptions = 2 did_est$figure$e2 # Number of treatment adoptions = 3 did_est$figure$e3

title: Getting Started with the didet Package
text: can obtain single aggregation estimate taking time series mean ATEM estimates obtained specification, follows: ATEM estimation results : figure available case.
code: # DiD estimation did_est <- didet::didet(yname = "Y",                         dname = "D",                         tname = "period",                         idname = "id",                         xformla = ~ X,                         data = data,                         specification = "aggregate",                         alp = 0.05,                         nboot = 1000) # DiD estimation did_est$ATEM #>    t  s  r e      est       SE       CIL     CIU #> 1 NA NA NA 1 1.015266 0.124448 0.7722924 1.25824

title: Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns
text: vignette briefly reviews Yanagi (2023) “effective treatment approach difference--differences general treatment patterns”.

title: Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns
text: balanced panel data \(\{ (Y_{}, D_{}, X_i): = 1, \dots, N; t = 1, \dots, T \}\), \(Y_{}\): outcome variable unit \(\) period \(t\). \(D_{}\): possibly non-binary time-varying treatment variable unit \(\) period \(t\). \(X_i\): unit \(\) specific covariate vector. Suppose \(D_{} = 0\) indicates unit \(\) comparison unit period \(t\). goal assess instantaneous dynamic effects treatment receipt outcome. general treatment patterns, may many treatment paths, generally difficult estimate treatment parameters defined potential outcome given entire path treatment adoption. circumvent problem, Yanagi (2023) proposes effective treatment approach estimation.

title: Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns
Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns

what: Identification, Estimation, and Statistical Inference Methods
title: Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns
text: Yanagi (2023) builds Callaway Sant’Anna (2021) develops doubly robust identification, estimation, bootstrap inference methods ATEM parameter conditional parallel trends assumption. See paper details.

title: Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns
text: Similar staggered adoption case, can assess validity parallel trends checking “pre-trends”. specific, three time periods \(t > s \ge r\) effective treatment intensity \(e \neq 0\), define \[\begin{align*}   \mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, r, e) = \mathbb{E}[ Y_{ir} - Y_{ir}^*(0) \mid M_{,t,s,e} = 1 ]. \end{align*}\] can show \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, r, e) = 0\) parallel trends assumption. Thus, parallel trends assumption implausible find statistical evidence \(\mathrm{ATEM}(t, s, r, e) = 0\).

title: Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns
text: common practice perform event study analyses prior formal estimation. Thus, natural take event specification good starting point plot \(\mathrm{ATEM}^{\mathrm{E}}(t, e-1, e)\) set \((t, e)\), including ``pre-trends’’ assess validity parallel trends. , desirable examine treatment effect heterogeneity trying number specification. Finally, obtain precise estimates, recommended estimate ATEM parameter defined specification time-series average useful aggregation parameters, , \[\begin{align*}     \mathrm{ATEM}^{\mathrm{}}     = \frac{1}{(T - 1)} \sum_{t=2}^T \mathrm{ATEM}^{\mathrm{O}}(t, 1, 1). \end{align*}\]

title: Review of An Effective Treatment Approach to Difference-in-Differences with General Treatment Patterns
text: Callaway, B., Sant’Anna, P. HC, 2021. Difference--differences multiple time periods. Journal Econometrics 225(2), 200-230. Link Yanagi, T., 2023. effective treatment approach difference--differences general treatment patterns. arXiv preprint arXiv:2212.13226. Link

what: An effective treatment approach to DiD with general treatment patterns — didet
title: An effective treatment approach to DiD with general treatment patterns — didet
text: `didet()` function takes effective treatment approach difference--differences estimation general treatment patterns. method developed Yanagi (2023). details, see package vignette `vignette("didet")` `vignette("review", package = "didet")`.

title: An effective treatment approach to DiD with general treatment patterns — didet
code: didet(   yname,   dname,   tname,   idname,   xformla = ~1,   data,   specification = "event",   alp = 0.05,   nboot = 1000 )

title: An effective treatment approach to DiD with general treatment patterns — didet
text: yname name outcome variable dname name treatment variable tname name time period idname name unit index xformla formula unit-specific covariates included. form `xformla = ~ X1 + X2`. Default `xformla = ~ 1`. data data.frame balanced panel data (long format) specification character specifying effective treatment function. Options "", "event", "number", "aggregate". Default "event". alp significance level. Default 0.05. nboot number bootstrap repetitions. Default 1000.

title: An effective treatment approach to DiD with general treatment patterns — didet
text: list contains following elements. ATEM data.frame collects results ATEM(t,s,e) mover data.frame collects results probability mover stayer data.frame collects results probability stayer figure list contains ggplot2 figures ATEM(t,s,e)

title: An effective treatment approach to DiD with general treatment patterns — didet
text: Yanagi, T., 2023. effective treatment approach difference--differences general treatment patterns. arXiv:2212.13226.

title: An effective treatment approach to DiD with general treatment patterns — didet
code: set.seed(1) data <- datageneration(N = 1000, S = 4) did_est <- didet(yname = "Y",                  dname = "D",                  tname = "period",                  idname = "id",                  xformla = ~ X,                  data = data,                  specification = "event",                  alp = 0.05,                  nboot = 1000)
